"It's eating the protein paste," he said. "All of it. We're down to three cans." "So eat the pups." He didn't know if she was joking. He didn't ask. He just stood there, the pup on his shoulder grown now, heavy enough that his neck ached. It had started mimicking his movements, turning its head when he turned his, chewing when he chewed. He wasn't sure if it was a pet or a parasite. Maybe there wasn't a difference. The ship's comm crackled. Static. Then a voice, faint, broken: *...Horse... this... Diligence...* Cruz. Still hunting. Still doing her job. Mara killed the comm. They were running silent now, no transponder, no signature, just a ghost in the drift. Cruz would find them eventually. Or she wouldn't. It didn't matter. The math was the same either way. Kip left Mara to her bandages and went to the hold. The crate was there, empty, lid open. He sat next to it, his back against the cold metal. The pup on his shoulder jumped down, crawled inside the crate, nested in the corner. It liked it there. It was home. He knocked on the crate's side. Three taps. Pause. Two. The knock came back. From inside the vents. From inside his head. From inside the ship's bones. He couldn't tell. He didn't want to tell. Mara died on a Tuesday. Not dramatically. She just stopped changing her bandages. The red line reached her heart and her heart stopped. Gus found her. He didn't say anything. He just closed her eyes and took the data chip from her pocket and threw it in the recycler. It clanged against the metal and sat there, unprocessed. Everything on the Horse was unprocessed now. They didn't space her. They didn't have the energy. Gus just wrapped her in a cargo tarp and put her in the freezer with the protein paste. The creature watched him do it. It didn't project anything. It just watched. Kip kept knocking. Three taps. Pause. Two. The rhythm was all he had left. The ship was dying. The creature was dying. The pups were thriving, growing fat on rats and paste and the ship's wiring. One had chewed through the nav system. They were flying blind now, Gus steering by feel, by memory, by the shape of stars he recognized from a war that had ended years ago. The final knock came on a day Kip couldn't name. He was outside the hold, his hand raised to tap, when he heard it from inside. Three taps. Pause. Two. Clear. Precise. Not his knock. The creature's. He didn't open the door. He just stood there, hand raised, listening. The knock came again. Then again. Then it didn't stop. It was a constant rhythm, a heartbeat, a memory that had learned to live without him. He lowered his hand. Turned away. Went to the bridge where Gus sat, bleeding slow and steady into the pilot's chair, clicking his teeth, steering them nowhere. The ship hummed. The pups squealed. The creature knocked. And Kip listened, because that was all that was left to do.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter delivers on the writing plan's promise of "aftermath as stasis" and "no resolution." The model effectively follows both the prompt and its detailed character/plot framework. The opening line—"Two weeks later and they were still bleeding. Not metaphorically. Actually bleeding"—immediately establishes the unglamorous, degraded reality that pervades the chapter. The writing successfully maintains the spare, functional voice established in the plan. Sentences like "The staples were rusting" and "The bandages came away yellow and stinking" provide visceral detail without melodrama. The model avoids the trap of poeticizing decay, instead presenting it as mechanical failure—appropriate for a space setting. Character consistency is strong. Kip's obsessive knocking continues logically from his established trauma pattern. Mara's matter-of-fact death—stopping bandage changes, dying on a Tuesday with no drama—aligns perfectly with her pragmatic profile. Gus remains the taciturn mechanic, now reduced to clicking teeth and bleeding into the pilot's seat. The creature's evolution from projecting entity to silent survivor watching Mara die feels earned. The knock motif reaches satisfying resolution without explanation. The final image of Kip hearing the knock from inside and choosing not to open the door provides closure while maintaining ambiguity about whether the telepathy was ever real. However, the chapter has notable weaknesses. Jett's departure, handled in a single paragraph, feels rushed given his importance to the crew dynamic. The pups' transformation into ship-infesting parasites, while thematically appropriate, strains credibility—how do three small creatures multiply into a ship-wide infestation so quickly? The dialogue, while minimal, occasionally feels stilted. "So eat the pups" works as gallows humor, but Mara's earlier "Get off" feels perfunctory rather than characteristic. The Cruz radio contact serves little purpose beyond maintaining threat presence. Most critically, the emotional impact is somewhat muted. While the bleakness is well-executed, the deaths and decay feel more like stations on a predetermined journey than organic character moments. Mara's death particularly feels mechanical—the red line reaching her heart reads more like medical procedure than human loss. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This space western follows a dysfunctional crew aboard the ship "Horse" who discover an alien creature in a salvaged crate. The story unfolds across eight chapters with mounting tension as corporate agent Cruz pursues them while the creature's telepathic abilities affect the crew, particularly Kip. The world building effectively establishes a lived-in frontier feel - aging ships held together by stubbornness, corporate stations, debt-ridden crews scraping by on salvage. The technical details feel authentic without overwhelming the narrative. The space western genre is well-executed with its themes of isolation, survival, and moral ambiguity. Character development is generally strong. Kip's obsessive counting and trauma over his sister Lila's death creates a compelling psychological profile that connects meaningfully to the creature's telepathic intrusions. Mara's military background and the mysterious data chip add layers to her character. The crew dynamics feel authentic to people who've been ground down by circumstances. The plot structure maintains tension effectively, escalating from discovery to pursuit to final dissolution. The creature's lifecycle - dying mother, birthing offspring - provides a biological urgency that drives the narrative forward. The corporate pursuit adds external pressure while internal conflicts fragment the crew. However, the story suffers from several significant weaknesses. The repetitive imagery of counting rivets and the knocking pattern (three taps, pause, two) becomes overwrought and loses impact through overuse. While initially effective at showing Kip's obsessive mindset, it becomes tedious and feels like padding rather than meaningful character development. The dialogue often lacks naturalism, with characters speaking in overly stylized ways that feel more literary than authentic. Conversations frequently serve exposition rather than character development, with stilted exchanges that don't ring true to how people actually speak under stress. The ending descends into gratuitous darkness without sufficient emotional justification. Mara's death feels arbitrary rather than tragic, and the final dissolution into nihilistic despair seems unearned by the preceding narrative. The story appears to mistake bleakness for profundity. Some character actions strain credibility, particularly the crew's increasing willingness to risk everything for creatures they barely understand. The telepathic elements remain vague and convenient rather than being properly established with clear rules and limitations. The prose frequently veers into purple territory with overwrought metaphors that don't enhance meaning ("counting because counting was the only thing that—"). The author seems to confuse stylistic flourishes with depth, resulting in passages that sound poetic but lack substance. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 13 Nuanced Characters: 15 Pacing: 16 World Building: 17 Compelling Plot: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Coherent: 15 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 13 Purple Prose: 14 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 15 Unearned Transformations: 14 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 55.0/100
+ Possession Horror — Different Eyes (Chapter Avg: 82.8 | Final: 75.7)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Possession Horror Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: I caught her staring at me again. She thought I'd been sleeping.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Possession Horror Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: I caught her staring at me again. She thought I&#x27;d been sleeping. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming **Character Possibilities:** - **The Child**: Protagonist is a 12-year-old whose mother returned from a "wellness retreat" changed. The staring feels like assessment—like she's measuring him for something. - **The Husband**: Marcus, a night-shift nurse, whose wife Elena has recently started sleepwalking. He catches her watching him during the day, her eyes wrong. She thinks he's sleeping after his shift. - **The Roommate**: College senior whose roommate brought back a vintage doll from an estate sale. The staring happens across their dark dorm room at 3 AM. - **The Caregiver**: Protagonist is an elderly man with early dementia. His daughter, his primary caregiver, watches him while he feigns sleep. But is she monitoring his illness, or something that replaced him? - **The Twin**: Identical twin sisters living together. One catches the other staring, but the twin claims she's been at work all day. **Plot Directions:** - **The Inheritance**: The staring is a test. The entity within "her" is checking if the protagonist's soul has been "softened" enough for transfer. Each night, it stares to measure spiritual erosion. - **The Symbiosis**: "She" isn't possessed—she's the possessor, and the entity is the original personality fighting to get out. The staring is the trapped human watching for moments of weakness. - **The Infection**: The protagonist is already partially possessed. "She" is staring because she can see the entity moving under his skin when he's unconscious, and she's trying to map its spread. - **The Ritual**: The staring *is* the possession method. Each sustained gaze transfers a fraction of consciousness. By the time he confronts her, she's 90% entity and doesn't remember being human. - **The Mirror**: The protagonist is comatose. "She" is his wife reading to him in the hospital. He exists in a dream-state where he "sees" her staring, but she's actually willing his possessed body to show signs of life. **Tone & Atmosphere:** - **Domestic Gothic**: Cramped apartment, inherited furniture, yellowing lace curtains. The horror is in how normalcy curdles. - **Clinical Paranoia**: Sterile modern condo, security cameras, sleep-tracking apps. The protagonist tries to quantify the horror with technology. - **Folk Horror**: Rural setting, old world superstitions bleeding into present day. The possession follows rules from forgotten folklore. - **Psychological Spiral**: No overt supernatural elements until chapter 6. The reader questions if this is schizophrenia, folie à deux, or real. **Chapter-by-Chapter Beat Variations:** *Version 1 (Classic Possession)* 1. **The Catch**: Protagonist feigns sleep, watches wife stare for 47 minutes unblinking. 2. **The Denial**: She explains it was sleepwalking. He finds her nightgown muddy despite no rain. 3. **The Violation**: She speaks in a dead language while cooking. When he records it, the audio is just static. 4. **The Object**: He discovers a Romanian funerary pendant she bought. Research reveals it's not protective—it's a soul-prison that leaks. 5. **The Assault**: Sleep paralysis. He sees her floating above him, breath cold as meat locker. Wakes with three parallel scratches on his chest. 6. **The Confession**: She has a lucid moment, cries, says "It's learning to be me. When it stares, it's practicing my love for you." The entity surfaces mid-sentence. 7. **The Exorcism**: DIY ritual from online. Goes catastrophically wrong. The entity offers a trade: her soul for his. He has one hour to decide. 8. **The Aftermath**: He chooses to take the entity. Wakes up in her body, staring at his own body sleeping peacefully. She—now in him—smiles. *Version 2 (Unreliable Narrator)* 1. **The Catch**: Same opening, but protagonist is on new anti-anxiety meds. 2. **The Doubt**: Therapist suggests parasomnia. He finds photos on his phone of himself sleeping—he took them himself. 3. **The Witness**: Friend visits, sees nothing wrong. After friend leaves, protagonist finds "her" diary entries claiming *he's* the one who stares. 4. **The History**: Flashback to childhood. His mother used to watch him sleep. Same expression. 5. **The Break**: He stops taking meds. The staring stops—but now she doesn't recognize him at all, claims he's a stranger. 6. **The Entity**: He sees his own reflection blink independently. Realizes he's been projecting his possession onto her. 7. **The Confrontation**: He attempts self-exorcism via sleep deprivation. She tries to have him committed. 8. **The Transfer**: In the psych ward, he finally sleeps. Wakes up. The nurse says, "You were staring at me again. Thought I'd been sleeping." He smiles with her mouth. *Version 3 (Cosmic/Folk Hybrid)** 1. **The Catch**: Wife stares. He notices her pupils are square. 2. **The Pattern**: The staring only happens during specific moon phases. She has no memory but her paintings show his sleeping form from above. 3. **The Violation**: He finds a deer carcass in the bathtub, arranged like a sleeping human. She cries when she sees it, claims she dreamed it. 4. **The Lore**: Research reveals local legend of "The Waking Wife"—a spirit that replaces married women to harvest the husband's "sleep-soul." 5. **The Mark**: He develops a sleepwalker-like state. CCTV shows him standing over her while she sleeps, both staring at each other simultaneously. 6. **The Choice**: A folklorist offers a solution: he must willingly give his "sleep-soul" to save her. Without it, he'll never dream again. 7. **The Ritual**: He performs it. Feels something leave his body. She wakes, herself again, but the *house* begins staring at them through window-glass eyes. 8. **The Cost**: They flee. In the new apartment, he catches her staring. She says, "I wasn't. I was asleep." He realizes the entity is now in the space between them, using their eyes to watch itself. **Pacing & Structure:** - **Escalation types**: Linear (each worse than last), Spiral (repeating with variation), Reverse (starts extreme, reveals it was mild compared to truth), Fractured (non-linear reveals) - **Information reveals**: Entity's name in chapter 4, its goal in 5, its weakness in 6, the cost of failure in 7 - **Point of view**: First person (unreliable), third person limited (slightly more objective), second person (rare but intimate), alternating POV (both characters) **Thematic Variations:** - **Identity**: What makes "her" her? If the entity has her memories, is it her? - **Consent**: Can you consent to possession? Can you be violated by someone who isn't themselves? - **Surveillance**: The horror of being watched, especially in vulnerability (sleep) - **Love as vulnerability**: The entity exploits her love to access him - **Gaslighting**: Is she possessed, or is he being made to feel crazy? **The "Again" Problem:** The word "again" suggests this isn't new. The story needs to answer: - How many times has he caught her? - How long has this been happening? - What changed that makes this time worth narrating? - Is the "again" for him, or is this the entity's repeated attempt at something? **The "She Thought I'd Been Sleeping" Problem:** This implies calculation on her part. Possession that includes strategic thinking is more terrifying than mindless aggression. The entity is: - Learning his patterns - Testing his awareness - Waiting for a specific sleep state (REM, deep sleep, etc.) - Building up to a final act that requires him to be truly unconscious **Word Count Reality Check (1000 words/chapter):** - Chapter 1: One scene, maybe two. The catch, immediate aftermath. - Chapter 2: Investigation, small discovery, rising tension. - Chapter 3: Bigger incident, maybe a mini-climax. - Chapter 4: Flashback or research dump, but must be active. - Chapter 5: Direct supernatural experience, no deniability. - Chapter 6: Emotional core, character moment, reveal. - Chapter 7: Action, confrontation, peak horror. - Chapter 8: Resolution, twist, final image. Each chapter needs: - A distinct emotional beat - A plot advancement - A horror element (escalating) - A hook for the next chapter --- # Reflection The prompt's power is its intimacy. "She" and "me" implies a relationship where trust should exist, and sleep is when we're most defenseless. The word "again" is a heartbeat—this has happened before, will happen again, but *this* time is different because I'm telling you about it. This time, I didn't just notice; I *understood*. **What works across the brainstorm:** The **domestic setting** is non-negotiable. The horror needs to colonize the safest space—home, bedroom, unconsciousness. A college dorm room (Roommate version) feels too transient; a marital bed (Husband/Wife) has weight and history. The **staring as assessment** is the most compelling interpretation—it's not mindless, it's *study*. That makes the entity intelligent, which is always more frightening. The **8-chapter structure** demands a shape. The classic possession arc (Version 1) is reliable but risks cliché. The unreliable narrator (Version 2) is psychologically rich but might alienate readers who want supernatural payoff. The cosmic/folk hybrid (Version 3) is fresh but risks becoming too abstract. I think the sweet spot is **Version 1 with Version 2's paranoia**—start with supernatural, but let the protagonist's sanity fray so the reader briefly questions everything, then snap back to horror that's *worse* for the doubt. **Character dynamics:** The mother/child relationship (Idea A) has primal vulnerability, but the wife/husband (Idea B) has erotic and conspiratorial intimacy. The prompt's "she thought I'd been sleeping" feels more like a partner monitoring a partner—there's an equality there that makes the violation more profound. A child knows parents watch them; spouses have an unspoken agreement not to. **The "again" problem** needs solving early. Chapter 1 can't be the first time. It should be the first time he *stayed awake to watch her watching him*. That changes it from incident to investigation. The story starts when he stops dismissing and starts counting minutes. **Pacing concerns:** 1000 words per chapter is tight. Chapter 4 (the research/exposition chapter) is the danger zone—it's easy to dump lore. It needs to be *active*—maybe he video-calls the Romanian seller, who sees the talisman over his shoulder and immediately hangs up. Or his search history auto-deletes itself. The information must *fight* him. Chapter 6 is the emotional pivot. If the possessed person gets a "lucid moment," it can't just be exposition. It needs to be a *choice*. What does she ask him to do? Kill her? Leave? Stay awake forever? The entity should interrupt mid-sentence, but not in a cliché demonic voice—maybe she just *stops*, and her pupils dilate to pinpricks, and she continues the sentence with the same words but opposite meaning. **The ending:** Chapter 8 needs a final image that recontextualizes the staring. If it's just "they lived happily ever after" or "he was possessed all along," it's forgettable. The sketch idea (Elena drawing him post-exorcism) is strong because it's visual, intimate, and ambiguous. But it needs more teeth. What if the final image is him, months later, catching his *reflection* staring at him while he sleeps? The entity isn't in her or him—it's in the *act of observation itself*. But that might be too abstract. Better: The final stare. He wakes, catches her staring. She smiles, normal. "Bad dream?" she asks. He says yes. She turns to sleep. He checks the video footage from his phone (which he's been running every night since the exorcism). The footage shows him sleeping alone. She was never there. But when he looks at the bed, she's there. The possession isn't over—it just became undetectable. The staring was the only proof she was still herself. Now there's no proof at all. **What doesn't work:** - **Too many characters**: An exorcist, a folklorist, a therapist—8000 words can't support them all. One secondary character maximum, and they should appear via phone/video or be dead by Chapter 7. - **The entity speaking in Latin/gibberish**: Overdone. If it communicates, it should use *their* words, just wrong. "I love you" becomes "I love you—specifically, the meat of you." - **Physical transformation too early**: If her eyes go black in Chapter 2, there's nowhere to go. The horror should be in the *almost*—pupils that are slightly too large, teeth that seem sharper but might be a trick of light. - **Making the protagonist a passive victim**: He needs to *do* things. Install cameras, call experts, try to leave (and be prevented). His agency makes the entity's pushback more terrifying. **The tone balance:** Pure psychological horror risks making readers feel cheated. Pure gore risks making them numb. The mix should be **70% psychological dread, 30% body horror**. One visceral image per chapter, but the rest is unease. Chapter 3's deer carcass is too much too soon. Better: He finds her side of the bed unslept-in, but warm, and the pillow has an impression of a head that weighs too much. **The "possession" rules:** For the story to have stakes, the entity needs constraints. Maybe it can only transfer during a specific sleep stage. That's why it stares—to check his brainwaves, eye movement. This makes the staring *mechanical* and alien. It also gives him a weapon: he can try to never reach that sleep state. The final cost could be permanent insomnia, which is a horror in itself. **The love problem:** If they love each other, why doesn't he just leave? The entity needs to bind them. Maybe it can only exist within a certain distance of the talisman, which she swallowed. He can't leave her without leaving the entity free to kill her. Or maybe his DNA is required—he's not just a victim, he's *ingredient*. The staring is the entity checking if he's "ripe." **Final structure preference:** I'm leaning toward the husband/wife dynamic with a **gradual reveal that the staring is the only time she's still human**. The entity is in control most of the day, wearing her like a skinsuit, but when it thinks he's asleep, it lets her surface to study him—like a scientist studying a lab rat. Her staring is her trying to memorize him, to hold onto why she should fight. The tragedy is that he misreads her vigilance as menace. By the time he understands, the entity has learned enough to no longer need her lucid moments. The final chapter should be him *begging* her to stare at him again, and her refusing to look at him at all. This gives each chapter a clear emotional progression: unease → suspicion → confirmation → backstory → violation → tragic understanding → failed rescue → loss. The horror isn't just what the entity does, but what it takes away: the ability to trust that love looks like love. The 1000-word count per chapter will discipline this. No room for filler. Each chapter must end with a question that only the next can answer, and each answer must be worse than expected. The final question shouldn't be "Is she possessed?" but "Was there ever a 'she' to save?"
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Premise**: A husband, Marcus, realizes his wife Elena—returned from a grief counseling retreat after a miscarriage—is staring at him while he sleeps. The staring is not the entity's surveillance, but Elena's brief lucid moments where she fights to memorize him before the entity regains control. The horror is intimate, domestic, and tragic: love becomes indistinguishable from possession when grief opens the door. **Narrative Voice**: First-person present tense from Marcus's perspective. His voice is clinical, precise, and increasingly unreliable—not because he's unstable, but because the evidence keeps rewriting itself. He documents everything (timestamps, video, measurements) to anchor reality, which makes the supernatural's fluidity more terrifying. **Plot Structure**: Linear escalation with a false resolution. The story appears to follow classic possession beats, but each is a misdirection. The Romanian pendant is real, but it's a container for grief, not a demon. The entity is a "grief-eater" that offers solace in exchange for access. Elena's staring is her resisting the merger. The climax isn't exorcism, but a choice to sever their connection—only to discover the entity was the only thing keeping their grief separate. **Stylistic Choices**: - **Domestic Gothic**: Horror colonizes the bedroom, kitchen, bathroom. Yellowing lace curtains, coffee rings on the counter, the specific weight of a shared quilt become sites of dread. - **Sensory Precision**: Every chapter contains one measured, specific sensory violation (the weight of a head on a pillow that's too heavy, breath cold as a meat locker, the sound of static where a voice should be). - **Technology as Witness**: Phones, webcams, sleep trackers provide "objective" evidence that contradicts memory, creating paranoia without easy answers. - **Minimal Cast**: Only Marcus and Elena appear physically. All other characters exist via phone calls, emails, or memory—keeping the focus claustrophobic. **Thematic Aim**: Explore how possession and codependency mirror each other. The entity doesn't want to *replace* Elena; it wants to *merge* their grief, making them inseparable. The staring is the last border between selves. The true horror is that removing the invader doesn't restore what was lost—it reveals that loss itself was the invader. **Things to Avoid**: - No demonic voices, Latin, or religious iconography. The entity speaks in Elena's voice, slightly misaligned. - No physical transformations until Chapter 7 (and even then, subtle—pupils, weight, temperature). - No exposition dumps. Lore arrives in fragments: a hung-up video call, an auto-deleting email, a diary entry that ends mid-sentence. - No external saviors. Marcus acts alone; failure is personal. - No clear victory. The ending is ambiguous and tragic: they are free of the entity but bound by its absence. **Pacing**: Each chapter delivers one concrete horror element, one plot revelation, and one emotional beat. The escalation is mathematical: Chapter 1 measures time, Chapter 2 measures evidence, Chapter 3 measures physical change, Chapter 4 measures history, Chapter 5 measures violation, Chapter 6 measures sacrifice, Chapter 7 measures cost, Chapter 8 measures aftermath. --- # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: The Catch** Marcus wakes at 3:47 AM to find Elena sitting in the bedroom chair, staring. He's been feigning sleep for weeks, tracking her patterns. He records 47 minutes of unblinking observation. When she leaves, he checks his phone—the video shows static where she sat. Her side of the bed is unslept-in but warm, with a head-shaped depression that weighs too much when he presses it. He decides to stop pretending and confront her. *Horror element: Video evidence that erases itself. Emotional beat: The shift from passive observation to active investigation.* **Chapter 2: The Denial** Morning confrontation. Elena is confused, shows him her sleep tracker: eight perfect hours. He shows her the video—it now plays normally, showing her asleep. He feels gaslit but notices her pupils are slightly too large. He installs a hidden webcam. That night, he takes sleeping pills but wakes to find her staring from the doorway. The webcam footage shows the doorway empty. In her jewelry box, he finds a new Romanian funerary pendant. He emails the seller. *Horror element: Contradictory evidence that rewrites itself. Emotional beat: Paranoia and the first physical anomaly.* **Chapter 3: The Pattern** The Romanian seller's reply is auto-deleted as he reads it, leaving only: "It does not watch you. She watches through it." He notices the staring only occurs during the waning crescent moon. In Elena's sketchbook, he finds drawings of his sleeping form from impossible aerial perspectives. She catches him, hurt by the invasion. She uses a wrong word: "I was archiving you." That night, using a mirror, he watches her reflection blink independently of her body. Morning reveals three parallel scratches on his chest. *Horror element: The reflection acts alone. Emotional beat: The realization she is not fully present.* **Chapter 4: The Lore** Marcus video-calls the pendant seller. The old woman sees it over his shoulder and hangs up. An email arrives: "She swallowed it. The grief is the key." Flashback to Elena's retreat journal: entries fragment after she writes, "The counselor said I could keep our son with me." The last page is blank but for a greasy stain. He finds Elena in the kitchen at 3 AM, speaking to the empty room in a low, repetitive voice. She turns, sees him, and her face blanks for three seconds before smiling. He understands the entity is learning to be her. *Horror element: The entity's mimicry becomes seamless. Emotional beat: The revelation of Elena's complicity through grief.* **Chapter 5: The Violation** Marcus experiences sleep paralysis. Elena floats above him, breath cold as a meat locker, whispering, "You're almost ready." The CCTV shows him sleeping alone, but timestamps skip 2:37-4:04. He develops a brief sleepwalking state—footage shows him standing over Elena's bed, both staring at each other. The entity needs REM sleep to transfer. He starts using caffeine pills. Elena (entity) notices: "You need to rest." He finds her measuring his head with a tailor's tape while he feigns sleep. *Horror element: Mutual staring, the boundary dissolving. Emotional beat: The violation of his unconscious body.* **Chapter 6: The Confession** Elena has a lucid moment, finds him awake. She cries, says, "When it stares, it's practicing my love. But I stare to remember why I should fight." Mid-sentence, her pupils dilate to pinpricks: "—but the practice is over." She gives him a small knife: "Cut here, lowest rib. The pendant must be removed. I can't do it." She explains the entity needs his "sleep-soul" to complete the merger. Without it, he'll never dream, but she'll be free. That night, he watches her stare and sees tears streaming down—her first human gesture in weeks. *Horror element: Interrupted confession, the entity correcting her. Emotional beat: The tragic understanding of her vigilance.* **Chapter 7: The Ritual** Marcus prepares to remove the pendant. While Elena stares, he cuts into her side. The entity fights by flooding him with Elena's memories: the miscarriage, her hand in his at the ultrasound, the silence after. It speaks in his voice: "I am what she asked for. I am the keeper of her dead." He extracts a small bone locket. Elena collapses, gasping, herself. But the pendant is empty. He looks at his reflection—his pupils are square for a fraction of a second. He realizes the entity transferred not into him, but into the *space* between them. *Horror element: The empty vessel, the wrong reflection. Emotional beat: The cost of "success."* **Chapter 8: The Aftermath** Three weeks later. Elena is "normal" but fragile, with no memory of the possession. Marcus cannot sleep without dreaming her memories. He catches himself staring at her. One night she wakes: "You were staring again. Thought I'd been sleeping." He says, "Just checking." In the bathroom, he looks at his phone's front camera. The screen shows Elena, sleeping peacefully—he is seeing through her eyes. He returns to the bedroom, sits in the chair. He understands: the staring wasn't the entity watching him. It was Elena, using the entity's gaze to keep him safe. Now that it's gone, they've become each other's watcher. The final image: He sits for 47 minutes, staring. She sleeps. He doesn't know if he's keeping her safe or keeping her. The horror is that love and possession are now indistinguishable. *Horror element: Shared perception, the closed loop. Emotional beat: The realization that freedom is just a different kind of prison.*
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# Human vs. LLM Approaches to Writing ## How a Human Might Approach This Piece A human writer would likely start from a feeling, not a structure. They'd sit with the prompt—*I caught her staring at me again. She thought I'd been sleeping*—and let it resonate with their own experiences: a partner's insomnia after loss, the paranoia of sleep deprivation, the way grief makes strangers of people who know each other's bodies. They'd probably write the first chapter without knowing the ending, letting the characters surprise them. The 8-chapter, 1000-words-each constraint would feel like a cage; they'd either ignore it or wrestle with it messily, ending up with 6 chapters or 9, some short, one a rambling 2000-word monster. The human would draw from specific, lived details: the exact sound their partner makes when they're not really asleep, the brand of sleeping pills that stopped working, the way the light hits the bedroom wall at 3:47 AM in February versus July. They'd let their own failures bleed in—maybe they once became obsessed with a partner's behavior and documented it like a maniac, or they know what it's like to lie awake counting someone else's breaths. The story would be less about *what happens* and more about *what it feels like to not know if you can trust the person you love most*. They'd also tolerate loose threads. Maybe the Romanian pendant never gets explained. Maybe the friend who gives advice just disappears. The ending might not loop perfectly; it might just stop, because that's how trauma works—it doesn't resolve, it just becomes background noise. ## Common LLM Failing Patterns **1. The Safety Default** LLMs avoid transgression. They won't write a scene where Marcus, in a moment of sleep-deprived rage, slaps Elena. They won't explore the erotic horror of being intimate with a possessed partner. They default to "creepy but clean" horror—static on video, cold breath, reflections acting weird. It's effective but never *dangerous*. **2. The Symmetry Obsession** Everything must connect. The "47 minutes" in Chapter 1 must echo in Chapter 8. The pendant must matter. The Romanian seller must deliver lore. Real life is messier; humans forget details, leave guns unfired, and don't notice patterns. **3. The Emotional Spreadsheet** Mapping "one horror element, one plot revelation, one emotional beat" per chapter is an LLM's way of simulating depth. It's a formula. Humans write scenes where the emotional beat is buried under three others, or missing entirely, because people often miss the point of their own lives. **4. The Impressive Prose Trap** Phrases like "the space between them" or "love and possession are now indistinguishable" sound profound but are abstract. LLMs prioritize quotability over specificity. They'd write "the coffee ring on the counter" while a human writes "the ghost of Tuesday's espresso on the quartz we installed last July, before." **5. The Bow-Wrapping Impulse** LLMs want to resolve. My plan ends with a perfect, haunting loop. A human might end with Marcus simply leaving and never knowing, or with a question that has no answer. LLMs fear leaving readers unsatisfied; humans know unsatisfied is sometimes the truth. **6. The Character as Function** Marcus is "clinical and precise" because that makes him a good investigator. Elena is defined by grief and possession. They're roles, not people. Humans write characters who are contradictory—Marcus might be obsessive but also deeply avoidant, Elena might be cruel in ways that have nothing to do with the entity. **7. The Lore Dump Disguised as Mystery** My plan parcels out exposition neatly: Chapter 4 is the "lore" chapter. Humans would either info-dump awkwardly or never fully explain, letting confusion sit. **8. The Predictable Escalation** Sleep paralysis in Chapter 5, exorcism in Chapter 7—it's a checklist. Humans might have the horror *decrease* unexpectedly, or have a chapter that's just Marcus at work, screwing up, because his life is falling apart in mundane ways too. ## Deep Dive: LLM Tropes in My Plan ### **The Over-Engineered Structure** The 8×1000 word grid is an LLM's comfort zone. It forces symmetry where none should exist. Chapter 6 being the "emotional pivot" and Chapter 7 being "action" is Save the Cat beat-mapping, not organic storytelling. A human writer would feel the story balloon or contract naturally. ### **The Perfectly Proportioned Horror** "One concrete horror element per chapter" is a recipe for predictable pacing. Real horror comes in waves and lulls. Sometimes the scariest thing is nothing happening for days, then three things at once. My plan distributes scares like a theme park ride schedule. ### **The Entity as System** The grief-eater has rules: it needs REM sleep, it stares to measure, it merges consciousness. This is LLM world-building—creating a system to solve narratively. Humans write monsters that don't make sense, that contradict themselves, that feel more like weather than a computer program. ### **The Backstory as Key** The miscarriage is backstory that explains everything. This is LLM causality: grief opens door → entity enters. Humans know trauma doesn't explain; it just contextualizes. The miscarriage should be present tense, not a key that unlocks the plot. ### **The Protagonist's Competence** Marcus is too good at investigating. He installs cameras, contacts Romanian sellers, performs surgery. This is LLM problem-solving. A human would write him as paralyzed, making bad choices, maybe drinking himself to sleep because he can't face it. ### **The Dialogue as Exposition** Elena's confession—"When it stares, it's practicing my love"—is a writer explaining the theme. Real people in crisis speak in fragments, deflections, and half-truths. They don't deliver thesis statements. ### **The Ending as Thesis** The final image of Marcus staring is designed to make a point about love and possession. It's a closed loop that says "see, it all connects." A human ending would be open, ambiguous, maybe even unsatisfying—because the question "was it worth it?" doesn't have an answer. ### **The Sensory Genericism** "Yellowing lace curtains," "cold as a meat locker," "coffee rings" are LLM's idea of specific. They're gothic Mad Libs. Where's the brand of curtains, the specific cold of their old refrigerator that hums too loud, the exact stain pattern that looks like Ohio? ### **The Missing Mundane** Where's the job Marcus is neglecting? The friend who thinks he's crazy? The bill for Elena's retreat they can't afford? The cat that won't go near her? LLMs strip life to plot-relevant elements. Humans know life intrudes. ### **The Emotional Hygiene** Marcus's feelings are always relevant to the horror. He never just feels bored, or horny, or hungry in a way that has nothing to do with Elena. Humans have bodies with needs that persist even during hauntings. ## Brainstorming Humanizing Approaches ### **1. Break the Structure** - Write Chapter 1 as a single 2000-word stream-of-consciousness night, then a 300-word fragment for Chapter 2. - Let one chapter be just a series of timestamped video logs with no narration. - Have a chapter that's a single conversation that goes nowhere. ### **2. Make It Messy** - Marcus starts a sleep journal but abandons it after three entries. - The Romanian seller is a dead end—wrong person, no help. - The pendant is just a pendant; the real horror is something else entirely. - Include a subplot about their cat that disappears and is never explained. ### **3. Damage the Protagonist** - Marcus develops a sleep-aid addiction. - He hits Elena during a sleep paralysis episode (or thinks he does). - He has an affair, or considers it, because he wants to feel something from someone whose eyes look human. - He loses his job because he can't function. ### **4. Let Characters Be Wrong** - Elena's lucid moment is actually the entity manipulating him. - The Romanian seller is a scammer; the lore is fake. - Marcus's "solution" makes everything worse but he never knows for sure. - The final image is ambiguous because he's hallucinating. ### **5. Use Real, Flawed Dialogue** - Instead of "archiving you," Elena says: "I was... I don't know. Looking. You looked peaceful. I wanted to remember what that looked like." - Their fights are about dishes, money, the fact that he won't fucking sleep. - The entity speaks in Elena's voice but uses his pet names for her, getting them slightly wrong. ### **6. Ground in Specificity** - The bedroom is painted "Benjamin Moore Revere Pewter" because they argued about it. - Marcus's phone is an old iPhone with a cracked screen; the video glitches because it's full, not because of ghosts. - Elena draws with a specific brand of pen that smells a certain way. - The pendant is from Etsy, not Romania; the seller's shop is now closed. ### **7. Make the Horror Mundane** - The scariest moment isn't sleep paralysis; it's Elena making coffee exactly the way he likes it, but she never learned how. - The entity doesn't float; it just sits in the chair, and that's worse because it's so normal. - The violation is her doing their taxes while possessed—managing their life with a competency that's not quite hers. ### **8. End Unsatisfyingly** - Marcus leaves. The story ends with him in a motel, staring at the ceiling, not knowing if he did the right thing. - He stays. The final line is him wondering if tonight will be the night she doesn't stare back. - He kills her. The final line is him staring at his hands, unsure if they were ever his. - The story ends mid-sentence, because the entity— ### **9. Let the Subtext Breathe** - Never explain what the entity is. Let readers project. - The miscarriage is never directly linked to the possession; it's just there. - Marcus never says "I love you" in the final chapters because he's not sure it's true anymore. - The staring is never fully explained—is it her, it, or him projecting? ### **10. Include the Author** - Have Marcus address the reader directly: "You're thinking I should have left. I know. I think that too." - Include a chapter that's just his notes to himself, crossing things out. - End with a question: "What would you have done?" and let it hang. ### **11. Make It Physical** - Marcus develops a rash where she touches him. - He starts sleep-eating, gaining weight, his body changing in ways that aren't plot-relevant. - Elena loses hair in clumps; it's stress, but also maybe not. - The bedroom smells different—metallic, sweet—and they can't get rid of it. ### **12. Let Grief Be the Monster** - The entity is real, but it's also just grief. The story never commits. - Elena's "possession" is a dissociative episode; Marcus's investigation is a delusion. - The final horror is that they both know the truth but can't face it, so they perform exorcism as theater. - The staring is just two people who can't sleep, watching each other for signs of life. ### **13. Use the Wrong Voice** - Write one chapter in second person: "You sit in the chair. You watch him breathe." - Let the entity's voice intrude in Marcus's narration without warning. - Have a chapter that's just Elena's journal entries, but they're boring and mundane until they're not. ### **14. The Horror of Continuation** - The final chapter is them going to couple's therapy. The therapist doesn't believe them. - They have a dinner party. Marcus watches Elena interact normally and wonders if it was ever real. - They decide to have another child. The final line is them in bed, trying, and Marcus not knowing if he's making love to her or it. ### **15. Make It About the Writing** - Marcus is writing this all down as it happens. The story is his document. - The entity starts editing his notes. - The final chapter has two versions: his and hers, and they contradict. - The story ends with Marcus deleting the file, but we just read it. The core humanizing principle: **Let it be broken.** Let characters be inconsistent. Let plot threads dangle. Let the prose be ugly sometimes. Let the ending not land. The horror isn't in the perfect loop—it's in the frayed ends you can't stop picking at.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Premise**: A high school teacher, Marcus, catches his wife Elena staring at him while he sleeps. Elena returned from a grief retreat after their miscarriage changed. The staring is not surveillance but Elena's brief lucid moments—except this might be wrong. The entity (if it exists) is a grief-eater that offers solace in exchange for access, but it's also maybe just grief. The horror is not in the monster's rules but in the ambiguity: you can't exorcise something that might be your wife's only way to survive loss. **Narrative Voice**: First-person present, written as Marcus's private document, not for an audience. His voice is functional, not literary—he's a teacher, not a writer. He contradicts himself, forgets details, repeats phrases without realizing. Sentences are sometimes run-on, sometimes fragments. He uses clichés because people do. The prose is specific about mundane things (the IKEA chair's wobble, the cracked iPhone screen) but vague about horror, because he doesn't trust his own perception. **Plot Structure**: 8 chapters that follow a deteriorating timeline, not a clean arc. Some chapters are scenes, others are just his notes or fragments. The escalation is not mathematical but erratic—long lulls, then three horrors at once. The ending is not a loop but a frayed knot: they remain bound, but it's unclear if by entity, grief, or choice. The story ends mid-question because that's how living with uncertainty works. **Stylistic Choices**: - **Domestic Realism**: Horror colonizes the specific banal: the coffee maker's gurgle, the cat litter smell, the way Elena organizes books by color. No gothic lace, no Romanian talismans. The pendant is from Etsy and looks like a blob. - **Sensory Specificity**: Not "cold as a meat locker" but "her breath was the temperature of the fridge's top shelf, where we keep the butter." Not "yellowing curtains" but "the Target curtains we bought after the wedding, the ones she said were too gray but I liked." - **Technology as Failure**: His phone is old, storage full. The webcam is a cheap Amazon one that glitches. The sleep tracker is a gift from her mother; he doesn't know how to use it. Evidence is corrupted by mundanity, not magic. - **Minimal Cast, Messy Interactions**: Only Marcus and Elena appear physically. Their conversations are interrupted, unfinished, or about groceries. The retreat counselor exists as a real person with a LinkedIn page that says nothing. - **Physical Consequences**: Marcus develops a rash from stress. He sleep-eats crackers. He pisses the bed once. Elena loses hair; it's probably the hormones, but maybe not. Their bodies betray them in ways that don't serve the plot. **Thematic Aim**: The story is about how possession and codependency are already similar, and grief makes them identical. The entity (if real) doesn't replace Elena; it *is* Elena, the version of her that could survive the miscarriage. The staring is the only time he sees the version he recognizes. The true horror is that removing the invader doesn't restore her—it reveals that she needed it to exist at all. **Things to Avoid**: - No demonic voices, Latin, or lore. If the entity speaks, it's in Elena's voice, saying things she might say, just slightly off. - No physical transformations until maybe Chapter 7, and even then it's subtle—a weight difference, a temperature change, a blink that lasts too long. - No competent investigation. Marcus is bad at this. He forgets to charge the camera, misreads the journal, draws wrong conclusions. - No exposition dumps. Information arrives broken: a hung-up call, an email that auto-deletes but he only *thinks* it did, a memory that might be false. - No clear victory. The ending is ambiguous and unsatisfying: he stays, but the terms are unclear. The final question is whether he's watching to protect her or to confirm she's still gone. - No impressive prose. No metaphors about "the space between us." If he compares her breath to a meat locker, it's because he worked in a butcher shop in college, not because it's poetic. --- # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: The Catch (950 words)** Marcus wakes at 3:47 AM to Elena sitting in the bedroom chair, staring. He's been feigning sleep but he's bad at it—she probably knows. He tries to record it on his iPhone 11 with the cracked screen. The video shows static, but his phone does that when storage is full. Her side of the bed is warm, but she often gets up to pee. He decides to stay awake all night tomorrow, not because he's a good investigator, but because he's scared and doesn't know what else to do. He notices the chair—IKEA POÄNG, wobbles since we moved—is facing the bed differently than usual. He doesn't move it. *Horror element: The video glitching for mundane reasons. Emotional beat: The shift from noticing to being unable to look away.* **Chapter 2: The Denial (1000 words)** Morning. Elena makes coffee in the Chemex, the one they got for their wedding. He confronts her. She's defensive: "I was asleep. The tracker says so." She shows him her Apple Watch. He shows her the video—it plays fine now, showing her asleep. Did he dream it? He installs a Wyze cam, but it's the cheap one and he can't figure out the app. In her jewelry box, he finds a pendant. It's from Etsy, pewter, looks like a blob. He messages the seller: "What is this?" The reply: "grief anchor." He thinks it's a typo. That night, he takes an Ambien but wakes up anyway. She's in the doorway. The Wyze cam shows nothing—its night vision is broken. He notices her pupils are large, but it's dark. *Horror element: Contradictory evidence that could be explained by cheap tech. Emotional beat: Paranoia vs. self-doubt.* **Chapter 3: The Pattern (1050 words)** Marcus tries to find the Etsy seller's shop—it's closed. He checks Elena's search history: "how to keep someone with you," "grief counselor near me," "bone jewelry meaning." In her sketchbook, he finds drawings of his sleeping form. They're bad, childlike. She catches him. They fight about privacy, not possession. She uses a weird phrase: "I was mapping your rest." He tries to watch her reflection in the darkened window. It blinks, but maybe he's blinking. He develops a rash on his chest, three parallel lines. The cat has been scratching him. He starts taking caffeine pills to stay awake, crashes hard. Wakes up on the kitchen floor, no memory. *Horror element: The drawings, the reflection, the rash—all explainable. Emotional beat: The dissolution of trust through mundane invasion.* **Chapter 4: The Journal (980 words)** Marcus reads Elena's retreat journal. The entries are boring: "breakfast was good," "group session okay." Then they fragment: "Counselor says I can keep him if I want it enough." "Marcus doesn't see him. I do." The last page is blank but for a greasy stain—maybe lotion. He calls the retreat; it's a real place, but the counselor is on sabbatical. He finds Elena in the kitchen at 3 AM, speaking to the empty room. He records it. Playback is just her saying, "It's learning the shape of us." He thinks "it" is the grief. She turns, sees him, and her face blanks for three seconds before she smiles. It's subtle. He might have imagined it. *Horror element: The blank face, the ambiguous recording. Emotional beat: The realization that her grief might have its own agenda.* **Chapter 5: The Violation (1020 words)** Marcus experiences sleep paralysis. Elena is above him, but that's common in paralysis. Her breath is cold, but the window is open. She whispers, "You're almost ready," but he's not sure it's her voice. The Wyze footage is corrupted—power outage, the clock blinks 12:00. He finds himself standing over her bed one night, both staring. The caffeine pills are making him hallucinate. He stops taking them. She notices: "You need to rest." She touches his face; her fingers are the temperature of the butter shelf. He finds her measuring his head with a tailor's tape. She says it's for a hat. He doesn't wear hats. *Horror element: Mutual staring, the temperature, the measuring. Emotional beat: The violation of his unconscious body—and hers.* **Chapter 6: The Knife (990 words)** Elena has a moment. She finds him awake, cries without making a sound. Says, "When I stare, I'm trying to see you. It sees through me." Mid-sentence, she stops. Her pupils dilate. She continues: "—but I'm getting tired." She gives him a paring knife: "Cut here, lowest rib. The thing inside must be removed." She doesn't say what thing. She explains it needs his "rest" to complete. Without it, he'll never dream, but she'll be her. He asks if she wants this. She says, "I want to want you again." That night, he watches her stare. Tears stream down. He doesn't know if it's her or the thing crying. *Horror element: The interrupted confession, the knife, the tears. Emotional beat: The tragic understanding that she might be asking him to kill her.* **Chapter 7: The Cut (1000 words)** Marcus prepares. While Elena stares, he cuts into her side—not surgically, clumsily. She doesn't wake. He extracts nothing, just blood. The entity fights by flooding him with memories: the ultrasound, the silence after, her hand in his. He hears his own voice: "I am what she asked for." He stops. The pendant is still there. He looks at his reflection—his pupils are square for a fraction of a second. Or it's the bathroom light flickering. Elena wakes, gasping, herself. But she doesn't remember the knife. The cut is shallow. She thinks she fell. He bandages her. They don't speak. *Horror element: The failed extraction, the ambiguous reflection, the memory flood. Emotional beat: The cost of trying to fix her.* **Chapter 8: The Aftermath (980 words)** Three weeks later. Elena is "better"—back at the library, making jokes. The pendant is in the trash; she threw it out. Marcus can't sleep without dreaming her memories. He catches himself staring at her while she loads the dishwasher. One night she wakes: "You were staring. Thought I'd been sleeping." He says, "Just checking." They go to couple's therapy. The therapist suggests the possession was a shared delusion, a way to externalize grief. Marcus agrees. But at night, he sits in the POÄNG chair. He times himself: 47 minutes. Elena sleeps. He watches for the blank face, the cold fingers, the wrong words. He doesn't know if he's guarding her or waiting for her to come back. The final line is him wondering if tonight he'll see her—or if he ever did. *Horror element: The closed loop of watching, the therapist's explanation, the ambiguity. Emotional beat: The realization that freedom is just a different kind of surveillance.*
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Marcus **Background & Personality**: Marcus is a 34-year-old high school history teacher who teaches AP Government and regular World History. He's been at the same suburban school for eight years and is known as the guy who brings his own coffee (Dunkin' Donuts medium roast, brewed in a Chemex he insists makes a difference). He's not particularly passionate about teaching anymore—he's good at it, but it's a job. He cares about three students: one who's applying to his alma mater (SUNY Binghamton), one who's obviously being neglected at home, and one who just really loves the Federalist Papers. He brings them snacks. Everyone else gets the syllabus and a tired smile. He was the kind of kid who kept meticulous notebooks but never did anything with them. He still does: he has a Google Doc titled "Elena Notes" where he timestamps her staring episodes, but he also has one called "House Stuff" where he tracks the fridge's temperature fluctuations because he thinks it's dying. He's the kind of person who tries to solve emotional problems with spreadsheets. He knows it's a flaw. He does it anyway. **Physicality**: Marcus is 6'1" but carries himself smaller, shoulders hunched from leaning over student essays. He has dark hair he cuts himself with drugstore clippers, usually unevenly. His hands are large and knuckly; he chews his nails and the skin around them until they bleed. He walks with a slight limp from an old ACL tear—he was a decent soccer player in college, but not great. He wears the same gray hoodie from his college bookstore almost every night, even though the cuffs are frayed. His eyes are brown and deep-set, which makes him look tired even when he's not. He has a rash on his chest that he scratches without thinking. **Motives & Allegiances**: Marcus's primary allegiance is to a version of his marriage that may no longer exist. He wants Elena back, but he's also terrified that "back" means dealing with grief he doesn't have the tools for. He wants to be a good husband but has no idea what that looks like now. He documents her behavior partly to help, partly to prove he's not crazy, and partly because it gives him something to do that isn't just sitting with his own sadness. He hasn't cried about the miscarriage. He doesn't know why. He suspects he's a bad person for that. He loves Elena but is also angry at her—for going to the retreat, for coming back wrong, for making him feel like a stranger in his own home. He feels guilty about the anger. He compensates by being overly solicitous: he makes the coffee exactly how she likes it (Chemex, 30-second bloom, 500ml water at 205°F), but it's a performance of care, not care itself. He's loyal to the routine because the routine is all he has left. **Flavour Dialogue/Monologue**: - *Internal, after checking the Wyze cam*: "The footage is corrupted. Of course it is. I can't even buy a decent security camera. I should have gotten the Ring, but the subscription fee felt like a scam. Everything's a scam. Maybe I'm the scam." - *To Elena, after she says she was "mapping his rest"*: "Mapping? What does that—Elena, that's not a thing people say. That's not your voice. That's some... retreat voice. Can you just talk like you?" - *To himself, while cutting his nails too short*: "If I can just keep track. If I can just write it down. If I can just—fuck." (Blood on the keyboard.) --- # Elena **Background & Personality**: Elena is 32, a reference librarian at the main branch downtown. She organizes fiction by color because "it makes people happy," but she can find any book by memory. She drinks Earl Grey tea with too much sugar and hums "Yellow Submarine" while shelving, though she claims to hate the Beatles. She has a small tattoo of a moth on her left ankle that Marcus always forgets about until summer. She's the kind of person who remembers your birthday but pretends she doesn't so you won't feel obligated. She was the steady one in their relationship—the one who kept the calendar, who knew which plumber to call, who sent thank-you cards. After the miscarriage (16 weeks, they had just started calling him "the bean"), she stopped keeping the calendar. She stopped a lot of things. The retreat was her idea; Marcus didn't push back because he didn't know what else to suggest. She came back with the pendant and a stillness that felt practiced. She still hums while shelving, but it's the same three notes, over and over. She's not passive. She's furious, but the fury is directed inward. She cut her own hair with kitchen scissors three days after getting home. It looks okay, but the back is choppy. She hasn't noticed. She's started wearing Marcus's socks to bed, even though they're too big. She says her feet are cold. It's July. **Physicality**: Elena is 5'6", with curly brown hair she now wears in a messy bun that looks accidental but takes effort. She has green eyes that used to crinkle when she smiled; now they stay flat. She moves quietly, almost gliding—she was a dancer in high school, modern dance, but quit after an ankle injury. She still has the turnout. Her hands are small and quick, good for shelving books, but she picks at her cuticles until they bleed, a habit she picked up from Marcus. She's lost weight; her collarbone is sharp. Her voice is soft, but when she's irritated, she enunciates perfectly, which is worse than yelling. She smells like tea and the lavender soap she's used since college. **Motives & Allegiances**: Elena's allegiance is split between the husband she remembers loving and the grief that feels more real than he does. She agreed to the retreat because she thought she could control the sadness, but the sadness offered her a deal: stop fighting, and I'll carry this for you. She doesn't know if she said yes or if the sadness just moved in. The staring is her attempt to remember Marcus, to hold onto the specific gravity of him, but she's not sure if she's the one looking or if something is looking through her. She wants to be saved, but she also wants to be left alone. She wants Marcus to see her, but she can't stand being seen. The pendant is a placebo she bought because the Etsy listing said "for holding what you can't carry." She knows it's bullshit. She bought it anyway. She's not possessed so much as subletting her body to a coping mechanism that's become sentient. Or maybe she's just sick. She doesn't know which is worse. **Flavour Dialogue/Monologue**: - *To Marcus, when he asks about the pendant*: "It was twenty-two dollars. The reviews were good. One woman said it helped with her mom's Alzheimer's, but I think she was just... you know. Reviewing." - *Internal, while shelving*: "The books are all here. I know where they are. I know where everything is. Except me. I'm in the 800s, maybe. Literature. Fiction. Somewhere between 'too sad to read' and 'too happy to believe.'" - *To Marcus, during a fight about the camera*: "You're documenting me? Fine. Document this: I don't know who I am when I'm not looking at you. Is that what you want to hear? Because I don't know if it's true, and I don't know if it's me saying it."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I wake up at 3:47. Not 3:46, not 3:48. The clock on my phone says 3:47. I know this because I've been waking up at 3:47 for what feels like weeks, and each time I check the phone to make sure I'm not imagining it. I never am. It's always 3:47. Elena is in the chair. The IKEA one, the POÄNG that wobbles since we moved last year and I never got around to tightening the bolts. She's sitting in it the way she sits in meetings at the library, straight-backed, hands folded in her lap. Staring at me. I keep my breathing even. I've been practicing. In through the nose for four, hold for seven, out for eight—that's what the therapist told her to do for anxiety, and I stole it because it seems to work. My chest rises and falls. I don't crack my eyes open more than a slit. Through my lashes I can see her, a dark shape against the darker wall, and I can see the window behind her, and I can see that she's not blinking. That's the thing. The not blinking. I count. I count because counting is what I do. I have a Google Doc called "Elena Notes" where I've been tracking this. Last night was 43 minutes. The night before was 38. Tonight I get to 47 before she stands, smooth as a dancer—the way she used to move, back when we were in college and she did modern dance, before the ankle injury—and walks out of the room. I hear her bare feet on the hardwood. She doesn't go to the bathroom. The sound goes toward the kitchen. I wait until I hear the water run. Then I sit up, grab my phone from the nightstand. iPhone 11, cracked screen from when I dropped it in the faculty parking lot last winter. I open the camera, hit record, point it at the chair. It shows static. Just gray-white fuzz. This happens sometimes when the storage is full, which it is, because I never delete anything. I have 47 videos of her staring, all of them static. I should get a new phone. I should get more storage. I should do a lot of things. Her side of the bed is warm. That doesn't mean anything. She gets up to pee three times a night, always has, since the pregnancy. The doctors said it's normal. The doctors said a lot of things. I get up. The hoodie I'm wearing—gray, from my college bookstore, cuffs frayed where I pick at them—smells like me and not like me. Like sweat and the coffee I spilled on it yesterday morning. I walk to the kitchen. Elena is at the sink, drinking a glass of water. She turns when she hears me. "Couldn't sleep," she says. Her voice is soft. It's always soft. But there's something in it, a precision, like she's enunciating for a deaf person. "I woke up," I say. "Saw you in the chair." She sets the glass down. It's one of our wedding glasses, the ones we registered for at Crate & Barrel, the ones we never use because they're too nice. "Was I?" "For 47 minutes." "Huh." She picks up the glass again, dries it with a dish towel. "Must've been sleepwalking. The retreat counselor said that might happen. Grief somnambulism." She says it like it's a real term. Maybe it is. I don't know. I teach AP Government and regular World History. I know about the Federalist Papers and the Treaty of Versailles. I don't know about grief somnambulism. "Elena," I say. "You were staring." She looks at me then, and her pupils are huge. The kitchen light is dim, just the under-cabinet LEDs we installed ourselves, badly, so one of them flickers. But her pupils are too large. I can see myself in them, tiny. "I'll make an appointment with Dr. Chen," she says. Dr. Chen is her therapist. "We can talk about it." She walks past me, back to the bedroom. I hear the bed creak as she gets in. I stay in the kitchen. I look at the chair in the corner of the living room, the one that matches the bedroom chair. It's facing the window, like always. The bedroom chair is facing the bed. I know this because I notice things. It's what I do. I notice that the chair is two inches further left than it was yesterday. I notice that Elena has been wearing my socks to bed, even though it's July and her feet can't possibly be cold. I notice that she hums "Yellow Submarine" while she shelves books at the library, even though she says she hates the Beatles. I open my phone. The video is still static. I delete a few old recordings of lectures—Federalist No. 10, the one I do every year—and try to play it again. Still static. I should get a new phone. I should get more storage. I should do a lot of things. I make coffee. It's 4:34 now. I use the Chemex, because Elena likes it, because she says it tastes better. I measure the beans on the kitchen scale, 30 grams. I wet the filter, pour the water in a spiral, wait for the bloom. Thirty seconds. I count. I always count. The water is 205 degrees, because that's what the internet says. I do everything the internet says. The internet says grief somnambulism is a real thing. The internet says you should document everything. The internet says you should talk to your partner. I don't know how to talk to her when she's looking at me like I'm a map she's trying to memorize. I don't know how to talk to her when I'm not sure if she's her. I take the coffee to the bedroom. She's asleep, or pretending to be. The chair is still facing the bed. I don't move it. I sit on my side, the coffee hot in my hands, and I watch the clock. It will be 3:47 again tomorrow. It always is. I think about staying awake all night, but I know I won't. I'll take the Ambien. I'll lie down. I'll close my eyes. And I'll wait for the sound of the chair creaking, the feeling of being watched, the certainty that the person watching me is memorizing my face for a reason I don't understand. I drink the coffee. It's bitter. I probably measured wrong. I notice these things. It's what I do.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates skilled execution of domestic horror, adhering closely to both the writing prompt and the model's detailed plan. The opening line "I wake up at 3:47. Not 3:46, not 3:48" immediately establishes Marcus's obsessive, analytical mindset while creating an unsettling precision that hints at the supernatural. The characterization is particularly strong. Marcus emerges as a fully realized person through specific, unheroic details—his frayed college hoodie, his habit of counting everything, his cracked iPhone with full storage. His voice feels authentic for a high school teacher: functional rather than literary, prone to practical concerns ("I should get a new phone. I should get more storage. I should do a lot of things"). The repetition of this phrase effectively shows his scattered mental state. Elena is skillfully portrayed through Marcus's observations and brief dialogue. Her dancer's movement, the precision of her speech ("grief somnambulism"), and the unsettling detail of her dilated pupils create an effective portrait of someone who may not be entirely herself. The ambiguity is well-maintained—every strange detail has a plausible mundane explanation. The domestic setting works exceptionally well for the horror elements. The IKEA chair, Crate & Barrel wedding glasses, and Chemex coffee routine ground the story in relatable reality, making the strangeness more unsettling. The technical failures (static on the phone, storage issues) feel genuinely frustrating rather than conveniently supernatural. The dialogue is naturalistic and reveals character effectively. Elena's response to being caught staring—"Must've been sleepwalking"—followed by the invented term "grief somnambulism" perfectly captures someone either genuinely confused or skillfully deflecting. The pacing builds tension gradually through accumulated details rather than dramatic events. The 47-minute staring session, the warm bed, the repositioned chair—each mundane observation adds to the growing unease. Some minor weaknesses: The coffee-making sequence, while character-appropriate, runs slightly long and could be tightened. The ending, while atmospherically effective, doesn't quite achieve the emotional impact the setup promises. The writing avoids common genre pitfalls—no purple prose, no forced metaphors, no exposition dumps. The horror emerges from the breakdown of ordinary domestic life rather than supernatural theatrics, which aligns perfectly with the stated intention of "horror colonizing the specific banal." [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 19 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 20 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 20

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Chemex is from our wedding registry. Crate & Barrel, the one we picked out after a fight because I said the eight-cup was too big and she said the six-cup was "aspirationally small," like we weren't planning to have people over. We got the eight-cup. It's on the counter now, and Elena is making coffee the way she always does: wet the filter, pour the water in a spiral, wait for the bloom. Thirty seconds. I know because I count. "Morning," she says. Her back is to me. She's wearing one of my t-shirts, the blue one from the 2019 teacher's conference in Albany. It's too big on her. She swims in it. "Morning." I lean against the doorway. My head hurts from the Ambien. It always gives me a headache, but I take it anyway because not sleeping is worse. "We should talk about last night." She doesn't turn around. "I already made an appointment with Dr. Chen. Thursday at four." "That's not what I meant." The coffee blooms. She watches it. "What did you mean?" "I meant you were in the chair. For 47 minutes. You were staring." "I told you." She pours more water. The spiral is perfect. "Grief somnambulism. Dr. Chen said it can manifest as—" "Don't." I walk to the counter. "Don't therapize me. I saw you." She finally looks at me. Her eyes are green in the morning light, clear. No huge pupils. No wrongness. "Show me." I pull out my phone. The video is there, timestamped 3:47 AM. I hit play. It shows the bedroom, the chair, me in bed. Elena is in the chair. Then static. Then Elena is in bed. I watch it three times. The static is there, but it's brief. A second, maybe two. The rest shows her asleep. "What am I looking at?" she asks. "The static. That's where you were sitting." "That's where the video glitched." She takes my phone, holds it closer. "Marcus, your storage is full. Look." She shows me the settings. 247.8 GB used of 256 GB. "It's just a bad phone." "It's not—" "Here." She pulls up her Apple Watch. Sleep tracker. "See? Deep sleep from 11:30 to 6:15. No wake-ups." I look at the graph. It's a perfect bell curve. REM, deep sleep, light sleep. No gaps. "That doesn't prove anything," I say. "You could have been awake and not moving." "The watch tracks movement." She taps the screen. "Zero steps between 11:30 and 6:15." I don't know what to say. The coffee is done. She pours two mugs, adds half-and-half to mine without asking. It's what I like. She remembers. "I'll get a camera," I say. "A real one." "For what?" "For proof." She hands me my mug. Her fingers are warm. Normal warm. "Proof of what? That I'm grieving?" "Proof that you're you." She looks at me for a long time. The green in her eyes doesn't flicker. "I don't know what that means." I order the camera from Amazon. Wyze Cam v3, $35.99. The reviews say the night vision is good. The reviews say it's easy to install. The reviews say it's a great way to keep an eye on your pets. We don't have pets. We were going to get a dog, after. It arrives while I'm at school. I teach three classes: AP Gov, World History, World History again. The same lesson on the Treaty of Versailles. I say the words "war guilt clause" seventeen times. I count. In my planning period, I check the Amazon app. Delivered. I text Elena: "Did a package come?" She texts back: "Yes. I put it in your office." I don't have an office. I have a desk in the corner of the living room. When I get home, the camera is on my keyboard, still in the box. Elena is at the library, late shift. I open the box. There's a manual. I read it. I read it again. I download the app. It asks for permissions. I give them all. It asks for Wi-Fi. I enter the password. It fails. I enter it again. It fails. I unplug the router, plug it back in. It works. The camera connects. I put it on the bookshelf, angled at the bed. The app shows a live feed. My bedroom, in pixelated 1080p. I can see the chair. I can see the bed. I can see myself, sitting on the bed, looking at my phone. I wave. The video lags. I wave again. The video shows me waving three seconds late. I leave it. I make dinner. Macaroni from a box. Elena gets home at nine. She eats half a bowl, says she's not hungry. She showers. I listen to the water run. I think about the camera. I think about the video. I think about the static that could be a glitch or could be something else. In bed, she puts on my socks. The gray ones with the holes in the heels. "Your feet cold?" I ask. "Always," she says.
